$span(u,v) := \{tu + sv | t,s \in \mathbb R \} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^2$

Examining span of vectors: linearly independent vectors span all of the space they occupy

Note $0 \in span(u_1, \dots, u_n)$ always

In $\mathbb{R}^2$, this is quite easy

In $\mathbb{R}^3$...
- $span(u,v) : u,v \in \mathbb{R}^3$ is a plane
- if $w$ is not in the plane defined above, $span(u,v,w)$ is $\mathbb{R}^3$

Shortcutting pulling out spans from rref: 
- point solution is all free variables $= 0$
- each variable vector is obtained at $t_i = 1,$, all other $t = 0$ (that is, we pull out the $A_{ij}$ and flip the sign)

Write $A$ as combination of $u,v$:
$A = tu + sv$ => matrix, rref, then substitute in what you find $t,s$ to be
That is, $\matrixstart u & v & A \matrixend$

If $rref\matrixstart u & v & w \matrixend$ does not contain a $\matrixstart 0 & 0 & \dots \matrixend$ row, it spans the space. Otherwise, one vector is in the span of the others.
